document.docAuthor: Hayat, Mohammad & Khan, F. R. & Badruddin, S. M. A.
document.docTitle: Type depositories of Chalcidoidea (Hymenoptera) species described from the Department of Zoology, Aligarh Muslim University, India

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Type depositories of Chalcidoidea (Hymenoptera) species described from the Department of Zoology, Aligarh Muslim University, India

emphasis.docTitle: Type depositories of Chalcidoidea ( Hymenoptera ) species described from the Department of Zoology , Aligarh Muslim University , India

subSection.paragraph: MOHAMMAD HAYAT , F. R. KHAN & S. M. A. BADRUDDIN

paragraph.emphasis: Department of Zoology, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh 202 002, India e-mail: hayat.mohd44@gmail.com

subSection.paragraph:
The type specimens of 717 chalcidoid species described by taxonomists from the Department of Zoology , Aligarh Muslim University , India , and their depositories are tabulated. Table 1 lists the holotypes and other type specimens of the species deposited in the Natural History Museum, London, England (BMNH), National Zoological Collections, Zoological Survey of India , Kolkata, India (NZSI), Forest Entomology Division, Forest Research Institute, Dehra Dun, India (FRI), National Pusa Collections, Division of Entomology , Indian Agricultural Research Institute, New Delhi , India (NPC), and the Insect Collection, Department of Zoology , Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh, India (ZDAMU). The holotypes and lectotypes of 700 species are distributed as follows: BMNH (175), NZSI (34), FRI (28), NPC (131), and ZDAMU (332). The holotypes of 17 species could not be located in ZDAMU, but all of these species are represented by paratypes . A further 23 species whose types are not located in ZDAMU are listed in Table 2
.

Progress in taxonomic research on the Chalcidoidea (or any animal group), especially in India ,
is greatly hampered by the lack of knowledge of where type material is deposited or, even if this is known, then on the accessibility of the types because of the reluctance of some authors or museums to loan types to taxonomists. One of us (MH) faced such difficulties, including unfortunately the non-response for loan of material by a few chalcid taxonomists and others who published ‘new’ records of species from India
.

It should be expected that types are present in the institution (s) where they are stated in publications to be deposited. In our case, although types are stated to have been deposited in the Zoology Museum, Department of Zoology , Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh, India (ZDAMU), these were actually retained by the authors ( M.M. Agarwal , M. Hayat , S.A. Shafee ) in their laboratories. The availability of type material to other workers was solely their responsibility
.

Also, for various reasons, but mainly for the safe keeping, Hayat subsequently transferred the holotypes and paratypes of some species described by him, first to the National Collections of Zoological Survey of India , Kolkata (formerly Calcutta) (ZSI, now called NZSI), and then to the Natural History Museum, London (formerly British Museum (Natural History) (BMNH). Still later he transferred holotypes to the National Pusa Collections, Division of Entomology , Indian Agricultural Research Institute, New Delhi (NPC), and on the request of Dr. Sudhir Singh , the holotypes of some species were transferred to the Division of Forest Entomology , Forest Research Institute , Dehra Dun (FRI)
.

As stated above the type material of Agarwal, Hayat and Shafee were retained in their individual laboratories. Following the death of Agarwal and Shafee, the first author (MH) spent months locating the types of their described chalcidoid species in their collections and brought all the available material together in one place. The collection of chalcidoid types and other determined material (= non-type specimens ) are now kept in a separate room in ZDAMU.

The purpose of this paper is to inform other taxonomists of the location in ZDAMU and in other institutions of the type material of chalcidoid species described by taxonomists from the Department of Zoology, A.M.U. Another reason for this publication is that in spite of the BMNH being stated as the type depository of holotypes by Hayat (1998 , 2006 ), some authors quote the type depository as ZDAMU.

The type and non-type specimens were properly arranged with the help of the second author (FRK), including designating, ZDAMU “HYM. CH .” registration numbers for each of the types . The third author (SMAB) prepared computerised lists of the types and non-type specimens present in ZDAMU, and those deposited in the BMNH, FRI, NPC and NZSI
.

The holotypes of species deposited in the BMNH and some paratypes deposited in ZDAMU by Noyes & Hayat (1984 ; 1994 ) and Hayat (1983) are excluded from this work because these publications were the result of work done outside A.M.U., Aligarh.

The list is in tabular form ( Table 1 ). In the first column the species are arranged in alphabetical order, followed by the generic name, the name (s) of the author (s), and in brackets the year of publication. The second column gives the status of the types ( holotype , paratype , etc.). The third column provides the name of the depository and registration number, if any. The fourth column is for remarks, such as the source of information on some ‘presumed’ types. The table lists species in their original generic combinations. Any later transfers to other genera or the synonymy of the species are omitted. The references to the species are available in Noyes’ (2003) Universal Chalcidoidea Database.

Dr. J.S. Noyes informed M. Hayat that the BMNH does not give numbers to slide–mounted types and that some of the card mounted types are still not given type numbers. For comments on the status of some type specimens in the ZDAMU, see Hayat (1989a , 1989b , 1999 , 2003 , 2008a , 2008b ), Hayat & Shahi (2004) ,
Hayat et al . (2005)
, and Zeya & Hayat (1995) .

There are also species whose types could not be located in ZDAMU even though stated as deposited here by authors in their publications. We have considered such types as either retained or misplaced by the authors and such species names are excluded from the ZDAMU. A list of such species is given in Table 2 .

We are grateful to Dr. G.A.P. Gibson and two unknown reviewers for suggestions which helped in improvement of this paper. We thank the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR), New Delhi and Dr. V. V. Ramamurthy , the National Coordinator of the ICAR ‘ Network Project on Insect Biosystematics’ , for encouraging us to prepare lists of insects, including types , present in the ZDAMU, and for financial assistance for the development of insect storage facilities. We thank the Aligarh Muslim University and the past and the present Chairmen of the Department of Zoology , for providing space and other facilities
.
